content: > When and how to view your exam timetable.

metadata.title: Exam timetable
metadata.description: When to view your exam timetable, what to expect on it and what is an exam or assessment clash.

content:
[View your exam timetable](https://exam-timetables.sls.bris.ac.uk/)  
Once your timetable is visible, check that you can see all of the exams for the units you are enrolled on. If there are errors or anything is missing, [contact your school office](https://www.bristol.ac.uk/students/support/help/#school) immediately.

metadata.title: Exam timetable
metadata.description: When to view your exam timetable, what to expect on it and what is an exam or assessment clash.
metadata.h2: How to view your exam timetable

content:
Your timetable includes exams that start and end on the same day during [university assessment periods](https://www.bristol.ac.uk/university/dates/#academic). You can see the date, time, and venue of your exam(s).  
Most on campus exams start at 9:15 am or 2:15 pm.  
Select the exam venue in your timetable to get a Google map showing where the venue is.  
If your exam has seat numbers, these will be confirmed a few days before the assessment period starts.  
Your timetable will indicate if you have alternative exam arrangements. Find out more about what will be [displayed and how additional arrangements will be confirmed](/students/support/disability-support/study-support/guide-to-aeas/).

metadata.title: Exam timetable
metadata.description: When to view your exam timetable, what to expect on it and what is an exam or assessment clash.
metadata.h2: What's on your exam timetable

content:
Online exams that are run during university assessment periods are included on your timetable.  
Most online exams start at 9:45 am.  
End times of online exams will be available in Blackboard a few days after your timetable is released.

metadata.title: Exam timetable
metadata.description: When to view your exam timetable, what to expect on it and what is an exam or assessment clash.
metadata.h2: What's on your exam timetable

content:
Details of other assessments, including coursework, practical assessments, and timed assessments of four days or more, will be available [in your portal](https://www.bristol.ac.uk/assessment-marks). Select 'View assessment details'.  
You will be emailed when they are ready to view.

metadata.title: Exam timetable
metadata.description: When to view your exam timetable, what to expect on it and what is an exam or assessment clash.
metadata.h2: What's on your exam timetable

content:
You may have two or more different types of assessments scheduled at the same time.  
For example, a single-day assessment may run alongside a four-day or longer open book timed assessment. This means you may sit an exam during a period where you are also working on an assessment with a longer time frame. This is not considered a clash.

content: > What to do if you have a problem during your exam or assessment and who to contact for help.

metadata.title: Problems during your exam
metadata.description: What to do if you encounter problems during your exam, such as online exam issues, an error on the exam paper, or if there is a disturbance.

content:
If you are doing an online exam and experience any problems during the exam, telephone Student Services for help: [+44 (0)117 428 3000](tel:+441174283000 "tel:01174283000").  
If the upload time has passed, [contact your school](https://www.bristol.ac.uk/students/support/help/#school) for help as this is considered a non-submission.  
If you are doing a timed assessment and experience any problems, [contact your school](https://www.bristol.ac.uk/students/support/help/#school).  
Make sure you are familiar with the [end time and deadline for uploading your finished exam](https://www.bristol.ac.uk/students/your-studies/teaching-and-learning/assessments/).

metadata.title: Problems during your exam
metadata.description: What to do if you encounter problems during your exam, such as online exam issues, an error on the exam paper, or if there is a disturbance.
metadata.h2: Online exam problems

content:
If you think there is an error on the exam paper:  
1. Raise your hand to let an invigilator know.
2. Write what the exam question says, and what you think the question should say, in the margins of your answer book.
3. Answer the question as best as you can.  
The invigilator will write an ‘incident report’. We will decide if any adjustments should be made when we mark your paper.

metadata.title: Problems during your exam
metadata.description: What to do if you encounter problems during your exam, such as online exam issues, an error on the exam paper, or if there is a disturbance.
metadata.h2: Exam paper errors

content:
You should raise your hand to let an invigilator know, if you think:  
* part of your exam is missing, such as a paper or separate formula sheet
* the papers you have been given are incorrect.

metadata.title: Problems during your exam
metadata.description: What to do if you encounter problems during your exam, such as online exam issues, an error on the exam paper, or if there is a disturbance.
metadata.h2: Missing or incorrect papers

content:
If there is disruption in the exam hall, such as the need to leave the building, the invigilator will tell you what to do.  
No extra time is given, but the invigilator will write an incident report to tell the exam board about the disruption. They will investigate and decide what (if any) adjustments should be made.

metadata.h2: Disturbances

content: When you leave the exam hall, some students may still be writing. You must leave quietly and not disturb them.

content:
Find out what to do if you are ill and about to [miss an exam or assessment](/students/support/academic-advice/assessment-support/missed-exam-assessment/).  
Check[what you need to bring with you on the day](https://www.bristol.ac.uk/students/your-studies/exams-assessments/what-to-take "What to take into an exam"), and what you should leave at home.

metadata.title: Rules and regulations
metadata.description: Read the rules before your exam so you know what time you should arrive to the exam, our expectations of you during the exam and what happens if you are suspected of cheating.
metadata.h2: Before your exam

content:
* You should arrive at the venue at least 30 minutes before the start of your exam and enter the exam venue when instructed.
* Leave bags, coats and any electronic devices (including mobile phones and smart watches) in the designated area before finding your seat.
* If you have a seat number on your timetable, you**mustsit at your allocated desk**. Otherwise, you could be marked as absent from the exam.

metadata.title: Rules and regulations
metadata.description: Read the rules before your exam so you know what time you should arrive to the exam, our expectations of you during the exam and what happens if you are suspected of cheating.
metadata.h2: Arriving at your exam

content:
* If you arrive more than 30 minutes after the start of the exam, you will not be allowed into the hall and will be directed to speak to your School/Department.
* If you arrive late, enter the hall quietly and alert an invigilator.
* No additional time will be allowed for students arriving late.

metadata.title: Rules and regulations
metadata.description: Read the rules before your exam so you know what time you should arrive to the exam, our expectations of you during the exam and what happens if you are suspected of cheating.
metadata.h2: Arriving at your exam

content:
* Find out what happens if you experience a disturbance, exam paper error, or [problem during your exam](/students/your-studies/exams-assessments/problems-on-day/).
* If you have any questions during an exam, raise your hand and wait for an invigilator to help you.
* You must stay **silent at all times in the exam hall**unless you are quietly talking to an invigilator.
* If you open your exam booklet, read the exam questions, or start writing before you are told to do so by the invigilator, you will be reported for cheating.
* At the end of the exam, you must stop writing when the invigilator tells you to do so. If you continue to write, this will be considered cheating.
* When you finish your exam, remain seated and silent until the invigilator permits you to leave.

metadata.title: Rules and regulations
metadata.description: Read the rules before your exam so you know what time you should arrive to the exam, our expectations of you during the exam and what happens if you are suspected of cheating.
metadata.h2: During your exam

content:
* You are not allowed to leave the exam hall during the first 30 minutes and last 15 minutes of an exam.
* You are not allowed to leave the room and return at other times during the exam unless accompanied by an invigilator. This includes toilet breaks. If you leave the room unaccompanied, you will not be allowed to return.

metadata.title: Rules and regulations
metadata.description: Read the rules before your exam so you know what time you should arrive to the exam, our expectations of you during the exam and what happens if you are suspected of cheating.
metadata.h2: Leaving your exam

content:
Suspected cheating incidents will be reported to your school/department and dealt with under the [University disciplinary regulations](https://www.bristol.ac.uk/academic-quality/assessment/regulations-and-code-of-practice-for-taught-programmes/penalties/).  
If you are suspected of cheating:  
* you will be handed a 'Notice of Suspected Malpractice' during the exam and must explain to the invigilator at the end of the exam
* your exam answer book and any unauthorised material will be removed
* you will be given a new answer book so that you may finish the exam.  
Read the [guidance on academic integrity](/students/support/academic-advice/academic-integrity/).

If you are taking an [online exam](https://www.bristol.ac.uk/students/your-studies/teaching-and-learning/assessments/)or [timed assessment](https://www.bristol.ac.uk/students/your-studies/teaching-and-learning/assessments/), make sure you know what the submission rules and deadlines are.

metadata.title: What to take into an exam
metadata.description: What you can and cannot have on your desk during an exam. This includes calculators, dictionaries, Ucard, food, electronics, valuables, coats, pencil cases, correction fluid and more.
metadata.h2: On this page

content: You must bring your UCard to all your exams. There is a seven-digit student number on the back of your UCard. You must write this number on every exam paper you use.

metadata.title: What to take into an exam
metadata.description: What you can and cannot have on your desk during an exam. This includes calculators, dictionaries, Ucard, food, electronics, valuables, coats, pencil cases, correction fluid and more.
metadata.h2: What to take to your exam desk

content:
* You may only use a calculator during your exam if the exam paper instructions allow it. Your school will tell you in advance if your exam paper allows a calculator.
* All calculators must be left on the desk during the exam.
* Check with your school to see if your calculator needs to be approved before the exam.

metadata.title: What to take into an exam
metadata.description: What you can and cannot have on your desk during an exam. This includes calculators, dictionaries, Ucard, food, electronics, valuables, coats, pencil cases, correction fluid and more.
metadata.h2: What to take to your exam desk

content:
* You may only use a dictionary during your exam if you have permission to use one or your exam paper instructions allow it.Your school will advise you in advance if your exam paper allows a dictionary.
+ You can request to use a dictionary by completing this form: [request a translation dictionary in examinations (Office document, 50kB)](/media-library/sites/students/documents/forms/dictionaries-in-examinations.doc)
+ If permission is granted, you will be given a copy of the form which you must display on your exam desk.
* All dictionaries will be checked for unauthorised notes.
* You are not allowed to use an electronic translation device in any exam.

metadata.title: What to take into an exam
metadata.description: What you can and cannot have on your desk during an exam. This includes calculators, dictionaries, Ucard, food, electronics, valuables, coats, pencil cases, correction fluid and more.
metadata.h2: What to take to your exam desk

content:
* If you need to take medication with you to your exam desk you must make this known to the invigilator.
* Accompanying leaflets and packaging should not be taken to your exam desk.

metadata.title: What to take into an exam
metadata.description: What you can and cannot have on your desk during an exam. This includes calculators, dictionaries, Ucard, food, electronics, valuables, coats, pencil cases, correction fluid and more.
metadata.h2: What to take to your exam desk

content:
* Pencil cases must be transparent (clear) and must not contain any paper.
* Any pencil cases which are not transparent will be searched by the invigilators during your exam. This is likely to disturb your concentration.
* You are responsible for bringing your own stationery (pens/pencils/rulers/erasers) and equipment (such as calculators if the exam allows).
* Each exam venue has a small supply of spare stationery, but not enough for every student. If you have forgotten anything, ask the invigilator for help.

content: Display your card on the top right-hand corner of your desk, so that an invigilator can check it.
